oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Belt buckle
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One half of a Confederate "tongue and wreath" officer's sword plate with "CS" laying on top of a broken Confederate "Georgia frame" belt plate. The "CS" plate was a product of Haiman Brothers Manufactory in Columbus, Georgia. It was found in Meigs County near the home of Col. Newton Jackson Lillard. The "Georgia frame" was a common style issued by the Confederates to enlisted men. It was found on the Norton Farm in Meigs County, Tennessee. Col. Lillard commanded the 3rd Tenn. Inf. Regt. (Mtd." CSA.
